reviews.review_text: It is clear that the extra time they put into the pc port of this game was worth it.  The graphics settings are much greater than the two prior iterations, however at least in the first hour of gameplay, there have not been any bugs or glitches. The game runs at a consistant 60 fps on maxed out 1080p settings on my GTX 970.  So far, it seems that holding off and waiting for the pc release of this game was certainly worth it!

As a PC Port, this is definitely the best of the lot. PC players will remember the multitude of crashes that pestered XIII and XIII-2. I played this game on the PS3 and loved it, clocking over 200 hours on it.  All core gameplay remains the same, and Square Enix has rather generously given access to all DLC except the Aerith set. You're really not losing out on anything special. Outerworld has been disabled on the Steam port, making it potentially more difficult for PC players as they can't get Turbo Ethers and Ethers off random NPCs. As mentioned before, DLC does make up for this by providing fairly overpowered equipment. If you want to experience the game with some challenge, try not to use Yuna's Summoner Garb and Cloud's Soldier 1st Class.  I hate the fact that you can't truly customize your key assignments. This port forces you to bind keys to the PS3/Xbox configuration, such that Jump/O/A. Full customization of FFXIII and XIII-2 was possible. Why not here? This is arguably more important for LR, where button preses are even more important than past games. If you don't have a Numpad, you're going to find it difficult to find space to bind keys into a comfortable configuration.  First, some background. Lightning has awoken from crystal stasis 500 years after Chaos flooded the world. When Chaos flooded the world, it had the side effect of stopping humans from aging. Humans did not age, and thus no longer died of old age. They could, however, still be killed by monsters, or die of disease. Lightning was awoken by God, Bhunivelze, to be the saviour. Her duty is to save souls from the remnants of the world so that they can be reborn in the new world that Bhunivelze is creating. Lightning has 13 Days to fulfill her duty before the world ends.   Now let's address the content. Lightning Returns is completely unchanged from the PS3/Xbox version. So let's look at some of the graphics: The NPCs don't look great, the dogs look horrendous. However, the environments bring across each individual theme well. Lightning, however, is of course well animated, although there's some visible tearing in her hair when Lightning touches the crest on her chest where her L'cie mark used to be.  Story: One of the main issues with this particular installment of Lightning Returns is the terrible English translation which ends up contradicting itself. The English localisation does not differentiate between 'Heart' (Kokoro) and 'Soul' (Tamashi). This is a key point of contention within the mythos, and has to be cleared up. As a result, I highly recommend having audio in Japanese and reading the English subtitles. However, always keep an ear out for the above two Japanese terms, 'Kokoro' and 'Tamashi', as the English translation makes no distinction between the two.   Characters: One of the most obvious problems since XIII has been the bland, one dimensional characters. While we may be tempted to continue the bashing, there actually is justification for a one-dimensional character this time around. Imagine if you've lived for 500 years with no true end in sight. No new lives are being born, and death is common. Nothing changes. You'd be depressed too. Each character has their own motivations, but they all end up the same. 'I'm in despair, Lightning, save me whether I like it or not.' It is bland, and this time, understandably so.   Gameplay: I'm going to be breaking the gameplay down into 3 parts, Adventure, Time Limit, and Combat.  Adventure: Lightning Returns gives you four fairly large regions to explore. In each region, you'll need to clear a Main Quest, and do a fetch quest for the 5th Main Quest. The rest of the Side Quests are fairly simple fetch quests, which tends to be boring more often than not. The mythos is well fleshed out, however, and you'll finally understand what the hell is going on when you clear Main Quest 4. But as with non-linear stories, depending on the order in which you choose to clear the Main Quests, you may find yourself confused at one point because you may not have the context of XIII or XIII-2 to back up your knowledge.  Monsters are in limited quantity, as befitting a game where the world is ending. Large scale enemies like Zaltys and Zomok have a population of 30, meaning there are only 30 of them in the game. Monsters do NOT give experience upon defeating them. Instead, stats are given as quest rewards. Basically, the more souls you save, the stronger Lightning becomes.   Time Limit: Take it from a player who has over 200 hours into the PS3 version of this, there's more than enough time to do everything. The clock DOES dictate some actions. Some NPCs require you to report to them at a certain time of the day to advance a quest, and some quests are time-sensitive, meaning if you don't fulfill the requirement about visiting them the 'next' day, you fail the quest. You are going to have to keep track of things, so it is recommended to clear Side Quests city by city. As the days pass, monsters also get stronger and drop better abilities. Thus, please don't hunt them to extinction within the first few days. Take your time.  You start with 7 days, and you extend time as you complete the five main quests to a maximum of 12 days before the Final Day arrives. If you complete enough side quests, you unlock a bonus dungeon and a bonus day for a grand total of 14 days.   Personally, I like the time limit. XIII and XIII-2 had themes about time. The party of six in XIII were counting down the days till they turned into C'ieth. Serah was counting down time as well. Lightning Returns makes it literal, forcing it into your face, 'TIME IS PRECIOUS', and you only have THIRTEEN DAYS to save the world.   Combat: This is where Lightning Returns shines. Unlike XIII and XIII-2, where Auto-Battle was your main option, Lightning Returns has a very immersive combat system, and is extremely customizable. Think of Lightning Returns as more of an Action JRPG than the traditional turn based JRPG. The Stagger system makes a return, although it's not as necessary as it was before in XIII and XIII-2 for normal encounters. Do note that for Boss encounters, you are expected to know how to Stagger the enemy, so build up your knowledge on normal encounters, and check the Bestiary regularly.   You control Lightning; ;her equipment, every movement, every Guard, every attack. Both your strategy in setting up Lightning's loadout and your execution of your strategy is extremely important, and this is what makes combat in Lightning Returns so satisfying when you are successful. However, inversely, every failed fight is also the fault of the player. Not Guarding, or not reading the Bestiary to find out stagger conditions is a recipe for failure. There is good news, though. Tons of players before you have beaten this game, so if you need an active demonstration, Youtube is an excellent teacher. Unlike old Final Fantasy games, stat grinding doesn't win fights. Execution of your strategy does. Keep that in mind.  Summary: While the characters are justifiably one dimensional, the story itself is actually fairly decent as the mythos of this series of worlds is finally explained in greater detail. This is, however, let down by a bad English translation (I'm running on the assumption that most people speak English here...), which makes the story seem self-contradictory. As mentioned above, it is recommended to play with Japanese audio and whatever language you prefer.   The combat system shines. I would really love to see a combat system similar to this in the future, but with hopefully more customization of Locked Abilities. However, for new players, the learning curve might be fairly steep especially if you run into an encounter you're not prepared for. All I can say is, keep at it.   While I do recommend this, I can't give this game a really high score because of the HUGE GLARING FLAW in translation, which is integral to storytelling. 7/10.

This is my first review for a game I have been waiting for over half a year. TLDR at the end.  Good things overall:  - It's a good game. - It's not perfect, but it's a good port. - Good price. - Good cards. - Achievements are not hard (+100 hours if you want all of them) - Most DLCs included.  Good ingame mechanics:  - Lightning. - NG+ system like in Dark Souls II - Tons of items and garbs to get. - Tons of quests to do. - Tons of monsters to exterminate. - You can switch schemata mid attacks and do A LOT of combos, which makes the game more than just atackattackattack, switch and repeat. - The days system is not bad, it's just that most FF games are endless. This one is just different. - You only grind gil, you won't need to slay specific monsters for most missions as you will get the items eventually. - Missions are only hard if you don't explore (on a sandbox game, duh) - Game encourages you to go to NG+ to get upgrades and other items.  Not so good ingame mechanics:  - Game is only hard (but enjoyable) during NG on normal mode. It will be REALLY easy on NG+ even if you play on hard mode. - Enemies don't scale on each playthrough, while you do, The game becomes easier and easier the more you play. I'm on NG+ on hard and only final bosses and last ones are challenging... sometimes. - Some garbs are better versions of other existing ones, and others are niche and would require a complete garb setup to work. - Aeronite is a ♥♥♥♥♥. - Ereshkigal is a ♥♥♥♥♥. - Most weapons and shields are just enhaced versions of previous ones.  Note: Game tends to crash sometimes in the Dead Dunes laberynths for some reason.  TL;DR: Tons of stuff to do, good replayability potential, but it eventually becomes too easy because monsters don't scale and it starts to get boring. Lightning is love.  I'm seriously waiting for a mod to make enemies scale on each playthrough, it's the only thing keeping me away from wasting 1k hours in this game.

It's dead rising with jrpg battles where you control one character who switches among 3 forms with the aid of different outfits. Fashion is the best part of Dark Souls and the huge variety of outfits and the customization options for them are a strong selling point. Not just asthetically, but you can min-max the library of stats, attacks, and equipment to suit your playstyle.    There's several gigantic maps littered with sidequests as well as the excellent overarching main story quests to keep you entertained. Don't fret over finding every little sidequest, once you do the important missions just skip to the last day.   I'm still not sure why the game had to take place centuries in the future if everyone looks the same. How about having the game take place a single year in the future? Scant half-baked plot elements aside, this game is worth your time and deserves better than to be associated with the grindy ♥♥♥♥mess that was the first in this trilogy.

I was really hoping this game would make up for the disappointment I experienced with XIII-2. There's not a lot Square could have done to rectify the ridiculous convoluted story (90hrs into the trilogy, and I'm still not confident I could explain it to someone if I had to), but I think they have done the best they could to make it reasonably motivating. Games of this length have to be motivating to keep the player interested, and that's where XIII-2 fell down, and where Lightning Returns ultimately picks it back up. Part of this is due to the fact that the game is completely open-world, more so than any other FF game I've played (possibly due to the complaints the previous two XIII games got for being 'corridor simulators'). Literally all of the explorable world is accessable right from the word go, but you quickly realise that there is a logical order to the locations you should visit. The combat system is reminiscent of XIII, but rather than customising paradigms across the party, Lightning herself is able to switch roles on the fly and perform different actions. There is seemingly endless customisation options for these roles using the vast array of outfits which can be purchased from stores, found in containers or won from battles. The game looks fantastic at higher resolutions, in fact much better than I was expecting from what is essentially a port of a PS3 game. SE clearly put some effort into making great visual improvements, and it's just a shame the same effort wasn't put in to optimisation. At launch, this game ran pretty terribly. After a number of patches, the game runs acceptably, but was still prone to pretty serious dips in framerate for seemingly no reason. In conclusion, if, like me, you enjoyed the previous XIII games but were slightly put off by one thing or another, then I'd definitely suggest picking up Lightning Returns, as it makes an effort to correct most of the complaints the previous two games suffered, and it does it very well. It's probably not worth picking up if you havn't played at least the first XIII game, as it may not make a lot of sense - not that it does even if you have played it!

The game's introduction sequence does a very good job of grasping your attention and getting you to ask questions..   Unfortunately, all that awaits is endless MMO inspired fetch-quests, sub-plots that you really couldn't care less about and Time Restrictions that frustratingly get in the way of the plot and characters you actually want to see.  Gameplay is better or worse depending on how you look at it.. combat is smooth, customization is at an all time high but a cast of likeable party members has been removed entirely. It's only Lightning and her amazing cosplay talent so no more group combos like before.   The entire game is governed by a Game Over timer. The timer itself is not an issue, you gain additional time very easily by doing quests. The issue is all of the restrictions that come with it. Numerous zones of the game are locked off at specific times so if you have a quest there then tough luck. You have to report back to HQ everyday at 6AM. Some quests are vague as hell so unless you Youtube it then you will waste valuable time searching every corner. Honestly a lot of the time the game feels like a job and you have to organize each day like you are putting together a college schedule.. it really got under my skin.  I've tried to like the 13 series, I really have. The sad truth is that only original 13 game deserves its Final Fantasy title though even that was one of the weaker entries in the series. 13-2 and Lighting Returns feel like completely different games and do very little to actually improve upon the original with all the potential they had. Can we ever get a real sequel to a FF game that isn't an experiment designed to cater to a different demographic?   Really all they had to do was throw the original cast into a new adventure where they all had to band together to save the day.. but 13-2 gave us some time paradox non-sense with Serah who nobody cared about and newcomer Noel then Lightning Returns finally gives us Lightning but no supporting party members to tag along and threw in more fetch quests than WoW with a timer emphasis.-  If you read until the end then just buy FFX HD, FF4, FF6, FF7, FF9 or even 13.

An RPG who's main mechanic is time limits.  If you are a casual gamer/rpg'er/Final Fantasy player stay away. This game is a load of stess.  You have 14 in game days till the game ends. For every minute real time 'x' minutes pass in the game. This time does not stop for menues, dialog, nor battles. Missions are only avalible in a set time window inside those '14 days' and have requirments in them like 'find these 6 things and be at point Z at 7am sharp' STRESS STRESS STRESS  You don't gain exp or levels from battles but from competing quests (saving souls) you do get gil (money) and items though, but overall battles are somethign to avoid. So, again, stress.  There is a mechanic to 'pause time', for a time, but it's a finite resource in the game, only obtainable via completing more quests. In which you may be missing, or find yourself needing to use this finite resource to complete!  I am curious who the desginers thought they where making this game for as so many central game mechincs run completly counter to so many who enjoy RPGs and past Final Fantasies.  The central time mechianic is by far my biggest reason to cautioning people from buying this game. But there are plenty of other cons.    Dialog seems bad even by FF standards, graphics are quite poor, yes, certain things look pretty, but it seems like another step in what I feel like has been FF's direction of making certain things look good for screen shots, but everything else look terrible. Such a large studio on such a large franchise should have everything looking much better then this. So many just... boxs. They may be skinned like other things, but they are a straight up polygon box. Nothing is even bumb mapped. It's... really mind blowing for a game made past the ps2 era.  Buggy. If my controler turns off because I walked away for a while it reverts to keybaord/mouse controls and won't change back until you restart the game.  Lazy port. Menus literally tell you not to turn off your PLAYSTATION 3 when saving. uhg. Mouse curse floats over screen.  Spent an hour just getting the setting set the way I wanted because not only do you have to relaunch the game for most of them, the 'main' setting page doesn't seem to affect existing saves. Nope, have to load the save then open the menu and change those same settings there instead.  Honestly, I have grown so disappointed in the franchise over the years. I keep trying to like it again, maybe 'that one' just wasn't for me, trying to dawn some rose colored glasses of nostalgia for the franchise in which to grade it on a curve... but they dont' take. Square failed on this. This is a bad game.  I would have used Valve's refund policy for the first time ever on this, but unfortunatly between the time I spent getting the settings right, walking laps in frustration, and getting far enough in to the game to get a reasonable feeling for what the game will ACTUALLY be like (which I probabaly didn't even get there, always takes a while in any Final Fantasy game) I had rung up 3 hours 'play time', one hour past the max allowed for a refund.  Just skip this ones guys, Square really doesn't deserve the money. I'd go as far to say they should be ashamed, nothing contained within is deserving of the FF name. Nor a good review if it had been called something else and held at the standards any other game is.

I just chopped off half my review because the DRM is gone. I fully recommend this game to any jRPG fan.     The combat system is more flexible than the previous two iterations. It follows the 'scheme' design, but you ONLY play as Lightning in this version. She gets three 'schema', which are builds with their own set of ability points that you can switch between on the fly. You get to choose an outfit and equips for each scheme, and get access to four abilities for each one as well, essentially giving you a rock/paper/scissors style fighting system. The combat is pretty engaging. It's more active than the previous two iterations, and less like any other Final Fantasy because of this. Unfortunately, Lightning doesn't gain experience in this game...combat is optional, minus scripted fights, and only worth doing for items for quests. Which bites, because the combat is truly that enjoyable that I still find myself going out of the way to do. The scripted fights are all fairly unique and dynamic. The bosses are all interesting to go against and it is fun to figure out their weaknesses and defeat them in battle. Quests are how LIghtning increases her stats. Every time she completes a quest, she saves a soul and becomes stronger. This game is essentially 'Errands and Dress-Up Simulator'. But, it is a nice little wrap up to the trilogy, and provides closure to that cliffhanger ending that is FFXIII-2.

Time limit -   Just to get it out the way since its a none issue with traction for some reason..... After a day of grinding and exploring I can say the time limit everyone is so scared of means little to nothing against the gameplay; if anything it just serves as a catalyst to make gamers fight more often (which you have to do anyway) to collect something called EP that lets you stop the clock for a set amount of time. I'm still in the first day and I've completed 5 side missions, 4 parts of 2 different main missions, and have collected much. If the time limit scares you, don't let it  Review -   I'll make it quick, there are no bugs in my play through so far and the graphics look amazing. The FPS can be locked or stuck on Dynamic and the graphic options are all present. The graphic options are basic however with only Normal or Advanced to choose from and the screen size stops at 1920 x 1080. I love the cut scenes, action, and combat as its different but a take on a few things other titles had; if I had to explain it I would say a mix of FFXII and FFX-2 as you can move freely during combat and switch what you do by switching outfits during combat and there are a lot of outfits to choose from. This title ends the story and the gameplay gives a sense of urgency and grandeur you don't see often, I believe this game to deliver in both presentation and execution.

I throughly enjoyed this game. I had played it on the PS3 and was close to finishing it but never got the chance. I am glad I waited though, the additional graphics options for the PC were very welcome and the game looked and performed beautifully. I have a 4K monitor, and a high end setup, GeForce 970 etc... But really people, how many games actually perform well at 4K even with high end hardware such as that? The answer is not that many, most new release games I still play in 1080p so I will not complain about the capped resolution. This port ran buttery smooth at 1080p which is more than I had whilst playing on the PS3 anyhow.   I have been playing Final Fantasy games since Final Fantasy 3 on the Super NES, and always loved the length and exploration factor of these games. The one thing I did not like about Lightning Returns was the always looming time limit I had to deal with on the PS3. The time limit makes it feel like something other than a Final Fantasy game and that was my only major gripe about this game. Once again I am glad I waited to play it on the PC, as I was able to download a trainer for the game that allowed me to freeze time which basically removed the time limit. I was free to explore every nook and cranny of the game and thoroughly enjoyed the more Final Fantasy like experience it gave me.   Trainer or not, time limit or not, the game is still fun, and very much reccommended.

Five centuries after XIII-2 the world is going to be destroyed in thirteen days and it's up to Lightning to get the band back together ... in heaven. While it might not be as dumb as it sounds to me, what I do know is the plot will be delivered almost exclusively through forced exposition that DOES. NOT. STOP. You will hear conversation after conversation repeating the same exposition, often several times in a row! Need a thing? Don't need a thing? Don't worry, your loyal resident Navi, Hope, will remind you every five minutes to get that thing, even if it so happens you can't get the thing, don't want to get the thing or are trying to find a different thing.  Honestly, this game has opened up a new genre for me that I dub the 'chore' game. Lightning Returns is quite literally a series of expositional cut scenes intersped with fetch quests. The chore is both literal, the never ending fetch quests, and metaphorical, as in this game is a chore to play. Yet, as awful as that sounds, every character is in on this joke: even Lightning herself contually bemoans her fate before begrudgingly accepting these countless, thankless tasks. It's not a good sign when the lead character's only motivation is to acquiesce because she has to, but tell me game, what's MY motivation. Every quest, and I mean EVERY quest will work as follows: a person will tell you something they need, get that thing and take it to them. This either completes the quest or leads you to the next person who needs something. Yay. This formula will not be deviated from.   While we could have a philosophical debate that nearly all games work this way, other games usually try to pad this out a bit with dialogue, minigames, crafting, inventory management. Something! In Lightning Returns you are either fetching an item or looking for a person to fetch for. I would have been shocked if a SINGLE character you spoke with said, 'I can help you, right this way!' Spoiler alert: that will never happen, and neither will anything else. So it's basically what it looks like, a cosplay fetch quest fantasy. I'm not really sure what Square Enix was trying to create here but while I admit it might have some charm and appeal for some, personally I found it too limited to put up with for more than my recorded play time.

Finally some good news for the Final Fantasy 13 Trilogy on Steam! It's a decent port everybody!  This port doesn't use a launcher to start the game but instead just starts the game up from the get go and if you hover your mouse near the top of the window you will get a drop down consisting of a Quit and Reboot option, Graphical settings and a choice of 2 button layouts (where X and O (or A and B) get switched around). The game supports 30 FPS (Fixed mode) or 60 FPS (Dynamic mode). It also has graphics options including: Shaders, Shadows, Bloom, Lighting and others but you can only choose from two options from each; Standard (For lower end PCs) and Advanced (For higher end PCs).  I have never had a problem with the other two ports so I cannot talk from experience here but I have had no problems with this port of Lightning Returns and I have been playing it at its maximum graphic settings (that is until someone realeases graphical mods for it eventually). To be honest the only problem I have had is a very, very tiny drop in FPS for about 1-2 seconds when walking into a crowded area but it goes back to 60 FPS before you can really make a comment about it.  Overall it is a very well ported game in comparison to the other two FF13 games that have come to Steam and I am very happy with it.  And to make it even better it comes with the majority of the DLC and it only costs £11! It's a steal not to buy it!  Side Note: If you do experience problems with this port; please keep in mind that it *may* be your computer and not the game and also I am pretty sure there will eventually be solutions to issues in the community hub for this game!

This is the best PC port from the FFXIII series so far. There is some choppiness from loading in some of the larger city areas, but battles and everything else runs fine for the most part. There's no need to worry about technical issues like there has been for FFXIII and FFXIII-2, previously.  The gameplay is action-oriented this time, with a focus on timing your attacks and blocks during battle that is new to the series. The game in general has an emphasis on keeping things moving, rather than taking your time to think and explore. I am an old-school turn-based RPG fan, and it wasn't so action-based that I couldn't enjoy playing. I haven't found a battle so far that required timing skills to succeed, as long as I have setup Lightning's equipment effectively before-hand so that I had enough HP to survive despite my poor hand-eye-coordination, for example.  The story is bonkers, but that's just how FF games are now. It's a good thing the gameplay is fun enough that it doesn't really matter.

if you hate final fantasy XIII and final fantasy XIII-2, you're forgiven to think this game would disappoint you. As a long time fan of final fantasy series, I am one of these people who are alienated by Final fantasy XIII gameplay and only played the games because... well it's final fantasy.   However, it seems squenix has learned from its past mistakes. LR is truly a good game, the best in trilogy. the gameplay is fun, with a large open world and side quests that made you feel as if you are doing something and rewards you handsomely in the end.   Don't forget about the costumes. Lightning has a lot of attires and attributes that look too cool or just incredibly stupid (anyone uses that moogle hat during serious scenes?)  the only catch is the time system. At first it really gives a sense of rush. This game is designed to be SHORT. a day in-game equals to an hour. You need to finish the main quests and complete the side quests later with new game plus.  Story wise, the story is dragging FF XIII's mediocre plot and FF XII-2 overly confusing plot to a whole new level. Fortunately the writing is good, so it will keep you interested and intrigued till the end. I think this is the game where the writers explore Lightning's personality which has been neglected in the past two installments.  The PC port is wonderful. Squenix should make Lightning returns as the new standard when releasing a PC port since FF XIII-2 pc port is the most horrible port I ever played.
